CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Lech Garlicki;Mihai Poalelungi;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in ORG . At the relevant time he was attached , as a soldier by profession , to ORG in Liptovský Mikuláš .

CARDINAL . On DATE the dean of ORG at the above - mentioned military academy issued a disciplinary order with reference to sections CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) of the Military Service Act CARDINAL . In it the applicant was found guilty of a disciplinary offence in that he had grossly offended another person in the context of administrative proceedings before ORG in PERSON . The decision stated that his action constituted a minor offence under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) of LAW DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP The decision stated that the case related to a disagreement between the applicant and his neighbours and that similar problems had occurred previously . With reference to section CARDINAL(c ) of the Military Service Act CARDINAL , the applicant was fined CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) , which was then the equivalent of MONEY ( ORG ) . That sanction was considered appropriate in view of the danger for society of the applicant 's action . With reference to ORG , the applicant was ordered to reimburse the costs of the proceedings .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , arguing that the decision in question was premature and arbitrary as it had been taken in disregard of the relevant facts .

CARDINAL . On DATE the rector of the military academy dismissed the appeal and upheld the decision in issue . The rector 's decision stated that it was final and that it could not be challenged by means of an ordinary remedy .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with ORG . He alleged that the decisions given by the military authorities were arbitrary and that his right to judicial protection had been violated as those decisions could not be reviewed by the courts . He relied , inter alia , on LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG rejected the complaint for lack of jurisdiction on DATE . It referred to LAW and to its decision II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL and held that administrative decisions which had a bearing on fundamental rights and freedoms could not be excluded from the jurisdiction of the courts . The decision stated that the applicant alleged a violation of his right to judicial protection without having sought protection of his specific rights before an ordinary court . Had the applicant brought an action in an ordinary court , the latter would have been obliged to comply with LAW when dealing with it .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that any person whose rights have been affected as a result of a decision given by an administrative authority can have the lawfulness of such a decision determined by a court unless the law provides otherwise . However , the review of decisions concerning fundamental rights and freedoms can not be excluded from the jurisdiction of the courts .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that judges are independent and bound only by law . Under paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , judges are also bound by international instruments where the LAW or the law so provides .

CARDINAL . In judgment ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG held that , in the event of doubt about the power of an ordinary court to review administrative decisions , LAW must be applied , pursuant to which the interpretation and application of laws must be in accordance with LAW . It must in particular be examined whether the contested administrative decision concerns a person 's fundamental rights and freedoms as such decisions can not be excluded from the jurisdiction of the courts .

In that particular case ORG found that an ordinary court 's decision to discontinue proceedings , which resulted from an erroneous legal assessment of its power to deal with an action against an administrative decision , amounted to a breach of the right to judicial protection as guaranteed by LAW .

CARDINAL . NORP In decision II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL June CARDINAL ORG dismissed a complaint in which the present applicant complained about the ordinary courts ' refusal to review his superiors ' decision to fine him for a minor offence under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(d ) of LAW DATE . ORG held that , since the ordinary courts ' refusal to review the decisions on the fine had been taken in accordance with the law in force at the relevant time , they did not interfere with the applicant 's constitutional right to judicial protection ( for further details see GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In judgment LOC . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG held that under LAW , the public authorities were obliged to apply international treaties where such treaties guaranteed a broader scope of fundamental rights and freedoms than national laws .

CARDINAL . In decision ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ORG pointed out that the ordinary courts were primarily responsible for respecting the fundamental rights and freedoms which the LAW and international treaties guaranteed to individuals .

CARDINAL . In judgment II . ÚS CARDINAL of DATE ORG found that the ordinary courts had violated the plaintiff 's rights under LAW . The plaintiff complained that the ordinary courts had discontinued proceedings concerning his action challenging a decision of ORG by which he had been dismissed as a professional soldier . The courts based their decision on the fact that review of the decision in issue was excluded from their jurisdiction LAW CARDINAL § CARDINAL(d ) of LAW . ORG held that LAW was complied with only where a court examined whether an administrative decision contested by the plaintiff had a bearing on any of his or her fundamental rights and freedoms , regardless of whether or not the relevant law permitted a judicial review of such decisions . In the case under consideration the ordinary courts had discontinued the proceedings on the ground that the law excluded judicial review of the relevant decision , without considering whether or not that decision concerned the plaintiff 's fundamental rights and freedoms . In doing so , the ordinary courts concerned had violated LAW .
Decision II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL was included in LAW which was published on an unspecified date in DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) provides that , where a person falling under military disciplinary rules acts in a manner which fulfils the constituent elements of a minor offence , such action is to be examined under a special law .

CARDINAL . Section DATE ( as in force at the relevant time ) governs minor offences against civic propriety . Paragraph CARDINAL ) provides that a minor offence is committed by a person who deliberately offends against civic propriety by threatening bodily harm , by causing minor bodily injury , by unjustifiably accusing another person of a minor offence , by causing annoyance or by other rude behaviour . Under section CARDINAL ) , such a minor offence is punishable with a maximum fine of SKK CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that citizens who have been found guilty of a minor offence are liable to reimburse the costs of the proceedings to the ORG . The details are to be fixed by ORG .

CARDINAL . Section DATE lists the principal duties of a soldier . Subsection CARDINAL(j ) obliges soldiers to abstain from behaviour which may harm the authority of the armed forces or threaten citizens ' trust in them .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) defines a disciplinary offence as a wilful breach of a soldier 's principal duties unless it constitutes a criminal offence or a minor offence .
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that where a soldier 's action is qualified as a minor offence under LAW DATE , it is to be examined as a disciplinary offence within the meaning of LAW DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that a disciplinary punishment may be imposed on a soldier who has committed a disciplinary offence . Such punishments may be imposed under LAW DATE or pursuant to a special law in cases falling under section CARDINAL ) . Among such special laws , reference is made to LAW DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL lists disciplinary punishments which may be imposed on professional soldiers . They include ( a ) a reprimand ; ( b ) a strict reprimand ; ( c ) a fine ; ( d ) a prohibition on performing a certain activity ; ( e ) confiscation of a particular item ; and ( f ) a protective measure .

CARDINAL . At the relevant time section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provided that final decisions on disciplinary matters were not reviewable by courts , with the exception of cases where the sanction imposed involved deprivation of liberty of the person concerned .
Under Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , as amended with effect from DATE , final decisions imposing a fine are reviewable by courts .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that the military authorities implement the law by issuing personal orders , disciplinary orders , military orders and decisions on compensation for damage .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL(f ) , as in force at the relevant time , excluded judicial review of administrative decisions imposing sanctions on members of the armed forces unless such sanctions restrained the latter 's personal liberty or resulted in the termination of their service .
That provision was repealed with effect from DATE .
